STATE BOARD OF CONTROL Hon. E. B. Cowles, Commissioner Public Hon. George C. Junkin Lands and Buildings, Chairman Secretary of State K. L. O. Brian . Arthur Mullen Treasurer of State Attorney General RESIDENT OFFICERS Superintendent Steward STAFF Superintendent First Assistant Physiei;ui Second Assistant Physician Third Assistant Physician Fourth Assistant Phy 1W. Baxter, M. D. le Gidley MEDICAL M. W. Baxter, M. D J. W. Meehan, M. D \V. Y. Thompson, M. D _ S. C. Doran, M. D A. J. Pricke, Ph. G.

To His Excellency, Aahton C. Shallenberger, Governor of braska : Dear Sir: — I have the honor to submit this, the Eleventh Biennial Report of the Nebraska State Hospital. Ingleside, Xebr., covering the biennial period eonmeneinfj December 1, IJMtS, and ending November 30, 1910. At the beginning of the biennial period. December 1. 1908, there were ten hundred and forty-five patients in the Hospital of whom six-hundred and eighty-two M ere males and three hundred and sixty-three (363) females. During the period, four hundreci fourteen (414 1 patients have been received, of whom two hundred and sixty-one (96] rid one hundred and fifty-three (153) females. During this period there wer< hundred and forty-five cJ4-"> paroled; out of this number one hundred and seventy-eight (178) were discharged and sixty - seven (67) were returned from parole. Of the one hundred and seventy-eight (ITS; discharged, fifty-thr eighty-three (83) improved and forty-two 1 42 no change. At the present time there are fifty-one (51) on parol. twent males and twenty-five (2~> > females and four (4 escaped. We had two hundred and five (805) deaths, leaving ten him and sixty-one (10151 i patients in the Hospital. November 30, 1910, isting of six hundred and ninety-three malm ml three hundred and sixty-eight (368) females. We have maintained a daily average of ten hundred and sixty-one and one-third patients at a daily average cost per capita of 31 1-10 cent an annual per capita of $113.53. Realizing that the successful management of an Institution of this kind greatly depends upon employing men and women •aed of a high sense of duty toward those who may be placed in their care, it has been my constant endeavor to obtain such help as would assist in raising the standard of efficien. compare favorably with any Institution of this kind. I have visited several Institutions, both in the east and the west, during the past two years and, after giving due consideration to their methods of treatment and management. I feel safe in saying Till I n T 1 111 f^ Wl T l I I f^ t k TH T 1 * I l*i^ i^tt T t ?*H ill T 1 T w\ W^ 4~\^2 ■ tf^fc^T T w^ TT1

312 I^M) COMMISSIONER'S RKI'OKT IMPROVEMENTS II take jrreat pleasure in calling attention to a tew of the important improvements which have been made during my rintendemy. General Kitchen: The floor of the general kitchen was found to be in a verv unsanitary condition. This was entirely removed and replaced by a solid six inch cement floor. The ste.iin pipes which heretofore had been placed under the floor. >sitatin^ the taking up of the floor in case of repairs, were changed M that in future it will not be necessary to disturb the floor when repairs are found to be needed. I Boiler Room: The annual coal hill was found to be a very >us item in the maintenance account, and after inquiring and onally investigating several different methods of tiring as ial saver, we finally decided upon giving the Jones anto - ic stoker a trial. The old style prates were removed and e of the automatic stokers installed. After giving the old new style a competent and thorough test, we were able to irt a little over IS per cent saving in coal. We have also i enabled during the cold weather to keep not only a greater but also a much more even one throughout the who buildings. t Power House: All the expensive machinery has been over - ed and repainted. The walls of the power house have been led. painted and a brick Hoor replaces that of the dirt one • before. tA further saving of coal I nught mention was made by in - inur a 4."> II. P. motor to run the ice machine instead of the in engine which had heretofore been in use. This enabled us ut out one steam line and use the surplus electricity which iously had not been utilized. Cold Storage: The cold storage tu next given attention, as the wooden rs sings and mineral wool used for insulation had become mouldy and saturated, thereby throwing off an unwhole - some odor. This we realized to be a source of grave danger. The whole of the interior was torn out and entirely remodeled providing separate rooms lor meat and poultry, milk, butter, lard, vegetables and fruit, waking one of the most sanitary.

HOSPITAL FOR INSANE, LNGLKSIDE 313 useful and ap to date cold storages in the state. The material used was powdered cork, cement and lime. I Wards: Everything lias been done to make the wards erful and pleasant. .Most of them have been repainted orated, new furniture and rugs have been supplied when y. and careful attention has been given to sanitary eoa - on*. The result lias been that I ,im able to report there been an outbreak of any contagious disease. Food: It has been my constant endeavor to provide and wholesome food and of sufficient quantity, not only to the patients but also to those who are employed in the Hospital this has 1 n greatly appreciated by all concerned. AMUSEMENTS I Amusements both indoors and out have been amply supplied. ong a few of the most important that I may mention baseball park, provided with a covered stand for the women seats for the men. Several interesting g.tnies have been wit - led during the season, which were greatly enjoyed. Open air certs were given during the summer months. A band stand has n erected near the main building, which gives those patients > are unable to leave their wards an opportunity of hearing the :ic. Dancing during the winter months has also been provid- Iand greatly enjoyed by those patients who care to take part. lay also mention that a moving picture show is held once reek. DAIRY < Special attention lias been given to the dairy cows inasmuch i- I large number. 85 per cent, were found to be infected with tuberculosis. These animals were shipped to South Omaha and old subject to inspection and slaughtered under the supervision »f the state veterinarian. Many of the carcasses were wholly •ondemned as unfit for consumption, others partially remainder being passed. The healthy cows were segregi their offspring and other younger animals having replaced I lisposed of. Believing that too elose housing was one of the

314 given to better ventilation in the barn and to keeping the animals out in the open air whenever the weather permitted. HOGS IThe raising of hogs lias proven to be very successful and we at the present time about three hundred and twenty (390 . a a fine healthy condition. FARM AND GARDEN IAYe have had excellent results both from the farm and en during the past summer. The Institution is well supplied all kinds of vegetable! at the present time. NEW BUILDING tA new Srproof building which will tceomodate 120 patients been provided at a cost of $50,000 and will be ready for ipaney in a short time. The building in itself is the must tantial one of those erected on these grounds, and will be id of great benefit to relieve the congestion now existing in Institution. RECOMMENDATIONS Prevention of Insanity EAny action looking toward the prevention of insanity in opinion has been too long neglected. Cnlcss some check is ed upon existing conditions this matter will become a serious ilem for future generations. I To bring the matter before the present legislature. I shall ition only one case out of many, that have come to my knowl - e during the time I have had charge of this hospital. Mr. was sent to the hospital suffering from syphilitic dementia. After a time he made a slight improvement and was taken home by his wife and other friends. After spending a year or more at home it was found necessary to return him to the hospital: he being in a violent condition at that time, and dying a few weeks later without making any recovery. 1 am especial - ly prompted in bringing the matter before the legislature on the grounds that during the twelve (12i months this man was at

HOSPITAL FOR INSANE. INGLESIDE 315 home, and three (3) months prior to his death, a child was horn to them; and I feel under such circumstances that I am justified in asking that some action he taken. tWhat I would suggest for consideration is a state law pro - ng for the sterilization of chronic insane patients lx>th male female. I would also favor such a law applying in the case riminal rape, etc. I wish to say that in making thi - , I am advocating an operation (vasectomyi that would take away a man or woman's usefulness, hut on the contrary. Id he a factor in assisting to restore the patient to his or ber normal condition hoth mentally and physically. NEEDS OF THE INSTITUTION EThe present requirements, which I shall take the liberty of ng to your special attention are as follows: The laundry is ted in an old building. In the same building are the bakes Enter shop and paint shop. Should a fire, once gel started in r one of these shops it would mean the destructoin of the p building. The loss of the laundry would mean a terrible ter to an institution of this kind. II would suggest that sufficient money be provided to letatched. fireproof and modern equipped laundry. I would D suggest that a subway he built, commencing at the general chen and connecting the same with all the different buildings, should be sufficiently large for carrying food from the ki' the several wards. It would also be used for carrying all ies. hot and cold water, etc.. so that in the event of any leakage bursting they could be reached at once. This would do away h present conditions, which mean a constant digging and ring up of lawns and sidewalks when necessary to repair | It gives me great pleasure to thank and fully acknow the very important services rendered hy our able steward and competent corps of assistant physicians, and the other officers and employes of the hospital, in constantly and intelligently perform - ing their several duties. Their co-operation in this great work B the means of bringing this biennial period to a KM ful conclusion. To His Excellency, the Governor, and < lag the Hoard of Public Lands and Building! my sincere thanks for the courtesy, raluabh selfish support which I have received at your time both individually and as an official 1 you I have at all times fully appreciated place this Institution upon the highest plane :entleinen constitut I desire to expres: assistance and un hands from time t< >«ly. I can assur. your endeavors v if efficiency. Respectfully submitted, M. \Y
